attributes.title: Examining the association between child and parent reports of children’s interoceptive accuracy and attention
attributes.description: The aim of this research is to test the suitability of parent/guardian report questionnaires to assess the interoceptive accuracy and attention of typical, healthy children aged 6-18 years.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Examining the association between child and parent reports of children’s interoceptive accuracy and attention

other.value:
Two additional regressions will be conducted as part of the secondary analyses to explore the interaction between observer reports (BPQ and IAS), child age and child sex, and whether this interaction predicts CSF scores. It is possible that the effect of child’s age on the predictive effect of observer report on child report will differ as a function of child sex.

Regression Seven: CSF IAS scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report IAS score, child sex and child age as the predictor variable.

Regression Eight: CSF BPQ scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report BPQ score, child sex and child age as the predictor variable.

If there are sufficient parent-child pairs of each observer sex, and a sufficient range of parent-child relationships (in terms of biological parent/non-biological parent, and number of years living with the child) exploratory analyses will investigate how observer gender and parenting role affects congruence between observer and child report. If we are underpowered to assess these relationships directly, we will control for these factors by regressing out the variance associated with them to determine if this has any effect on all of the analyses above.

Appendix A: Adult Interoceptive accuracy scale (Murphy et al., 2020)

Below are several statements regarding how well (accurately) you can perceive specific bodily sensations. Please rate on the scale how well you believe you can perceive each specific signal. For example, if you often feel you need to urinate and then realise you do not need to when you go to the toilet you would rate your accuracy perceiving
this bodily signal as low.

Please only rate how well you can perceive these signals without using external cues, for example, if you can only perceive how fast your heart is beating when you measure it by taking your pulse this would not count as accurate internal perception.

(Rating Scale: Disagree Strongly, Disagree, Neither agree nor disagree, Agree, Strongly Agree)

Appendix F: Interoceptive Accuracy Scale - Observer Report

Written below are some sentences about how well (accurately) the child can feel things inside their body. Please read these sentences and use the scale to tell us whether they fit with the child. If you think the statement fits them completely, please circle strongly agree. If you don’t think it fits them at all, please circle strongly disagree.  

It is very important that you only tell us how well you think they can feel what’s inside their body without using signs from outside of their body. For example, if they can only tell their heart is beating fast by feeling their heartbeat with their hands, this would not count as correctly feeling when their heart is beating quickly.  

How will I know if the child I care for can feel this accurately?

Some of these questions will be difficult to answer, and that's completely fine. Thinking about the following two questions might be helpful when making your decision:

When have I noticed signs of the sensation? For example, for cold temperatures, you may remember a time that they had goosebumps or were shivering. Similarly, for hot temperatures, you may remember them sweating.

How did they behave as a result of this sensation? If they were visibly cold and put on an extra layer of clothing, or visibly hot and removed an item of clothing, you could assume that are good at accurately feeling when they are hot/cold, and could select Agree or Strongly Agree. If they don't do this, or don’t do any other behaviour that might change their temperature (like ask for a blanket), then you could assume that they struggle to accurately feel when they are hot/cold, and select Disagree or Strongly Disagree. 

If some of these questions are difficult to answer, you will be given the opportunity to give us feedback at the end of the questionnaires. Since we want to know whether these questionnaires could be useful in the future, all feedback (both positive and negative) will be very helpful!

sample.value: Data will be collected until the sample reaches a minimum of 100 observer-child pairs (200 participants in total), or until the end of July 2020 if participant numbers exceed this. Based on a power calculation conducted in Gpower (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009), this will provide 80% power to detect an r value of .165 and above in a one-tailed test.

analyses.value:
Correlations will be used to determine the relationship between scores on the observer report and CSR, for the BPQ and IAS separately. Pearson and Spearman correlations will be used for data meeting and violating assumptions of parametric tests, respectively. 

Subsequent analyses will examine the extent to which the correlations between observer report and CSR change as a function of child age, sex, or observer interoceptive abilities. Firstly, whether child age, sex, or observer self-reported interoception interact with observer report in predicting child self-report will be investigated using enter method regression analyses. The following six regressions will be conducted:

Regression One: CSF IAS scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report IAS scores and child age as the predictor variable.

Regression Two: CSF IAS scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report IAS scores and child sex as the predictor variable.

Regression Three: CSF IAS scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report IAS score and observer’s self-reported IAS score as the predictor variable.

Regression Four: CSF BPQ scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report BPQ scores and child age as the predictor variable.

Regression Five: CSF BPQ scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report BPQ scores and child sex as the predictor variable.

Regression Six: CSF BPQ scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report BPQ score and observer’s self-reported BPQ score as the predictor variable.

If assumptions for linear regressions are violated, entry method robust regressions using the default tuning function in MATLAB will be used. If serious issues with multicollinearity are encountered, ridge regressions will be used.

Secondly, the correlation coefficient for observer report and CSR for each observer and child pair will be calculated to compute a new variable, labelled “Observer-child consistency” (OCC). Two sets of OCC scores will be calculated for scores of accuracy (using IAS scores) and attention (using BPQ scores). All OCC scores will be standardised, and Z-scores will be used as a dependent variable for additional analyses. Correlations will be conducted to examine the relationship between OCC and age, as well as between OCC and observer’s self-report (for both accuracy and attention). T-tests will also be conducted to examine the differences between OCC accuracy and attention across male and female children.

outliers.value:
Participants whose first language is not English will be excluded from the analysis. For all measures, outliers greater than three standard deviations above or below the mean will be removed. If missing data for a given participant is greater than 75%, this participant’s data will be excluded. Otherwise, missing data will be imputed.

All children will be asked to report whether they feel like a boy or a girl to determine sex. A third option will also be presented (Other/Not Sure/I Don’t Know). Carers will also be asked the child’s biological sex at birth. Any child who chooses the third option, or any child whose gender identity differs from the sex at birth reported by their carer, will be excluded from the analyses, given that atypical gender identity could be a confounding factor for all analyses related to sex.

dependent.value:
The key variables of interest include:

Parent self-reported interoceptive accuracy: This will be measured using the Interoceptive Accuracy Scale (IAS; Appendix A), which is a recently developed measure of self-reported interoceptive accuracy (Murphy et al., 2020). The IAS requires participants to rate their accuracy in perceiving a range of body signals (e.g. “I can always accurately perceive when I need to urinate”).  The IAS contains 21 items rated on a scale from Strongly Agree (5) to Strongly Disagree (1). The range of scores is from 21-105, and higher scores indicate greater perceived interoceptive accuracy. Items in the scale are included based on either being related to typical sensations which have been described as interoceptive, or give rise to insula activation in the brain which is associated with interoceptive signal processing (Murphy et al., 2019).

Parent self-reported interoceptive attention: This will be measured using the awareness subscale of the Body Perception Questionnaire (BPQ; Porges, 1993; Appendix B). This scale has 45 items with answers on a five-point ordinal scale ranging from Never (1) to Always (5) and requires participants to rate their tendency to be aware of (notice) different body sensations (e.g. “Most of the time I am aware of my mouth being dry”).

CSR interoceptive attention: This will be measured using the simplified awareness subscale of the BPQ, adapted for children (Appendix C). This scale has 39 items with answers on a five-point ordinal scale ranging from Never (1) to Always (5). This scale was originally adapted for children by Palser, Fotopoulou, Pellicano and Kilner (2018). However, the present research will use more recent version which made minor edits to the adapted version for additional clarity (Barker et al., 2019).

CSR self-reported interoceptive accuracy: This will be measured using the child adaptation of the IAS (Barker et al., 2019; Appendix D). 

Observer report of child interoceptive attention: Observer report of interoceptive attention will be measured using a modified version of the awareness subscale of the BPQ (Appendix E). This version has been reworded so the questions are related to the perception of another person, rather than the individual completing the questionnaire (e.g. “Most of the time they are aware of their mouth being dry,” rather than “Most of the time I am aware of my mouth being dry.”). Additional instructions for the observer have been included to avoid potential ambiguity regarding how to answer the questions.  

Observer report of child interoceptive accuracy: Observer report of interoceptive attention will be measured using a modified version of the IAS (Appendix F). As above, this version has been reworded so the questions are related to the perception of another person, rather than the individual completing the questionnaire (e.g.  “They are always correct at feeling when they are hungry,” rather than “I am always correct at feeling when I am hungry.”) Additional instructions for the observer have been included to avoid potential ambiguity regarding how to answer the questions.  

Additional Demographic Information
A list of additional questions that participants will be asked can be found in Appendix G. These questions will be asked to obtain information relevant to our exclusion criteria (first language and atypical gender identity) as well as the primary and secondary analyses (sex, age and observer relationship to the child.

conditions.value: The study will have a correlational design, whereby child reports will be correlated with their respective parent reports. All participants will complete all measures designed for their age group.

hypothesis.value:
Previous research has suggested that interoception, defined as the perception and awareness of one’s own internal state, may be implicated in the development of a range of psychiatric and neurodevelopmental disorders (e.g. Eggart, Lange, Binser, Queri, & Müller-Oerlinghausen, 2019; Khalsa et al., 2018; Murphy, Brewer, Catmur, & Bird, 2017; Pang et al., 2019). Because of this, it is crucial to form an in-depth understanding of how, when and why atypical interoception occurs. Since this understanding relies on the accurate and reliable measurement of interoceptive abilities, it is important that measures are validated for use across a range of ages and cognitive abilities. While valid objective measures of interoceptive accuracy and attention should be the gold standard, existing objective measures have a number of limitations (Murphy, Brewer, Coll et al., 2019; Murphy, Brewer, Hobson, Catmur, & Bird, 2018; Ring, Brener, Knapp, & Mailloux, 2015) and are often too time-consuming for developmental studies. Self-report measures assessing both accuracy (Murphy et al., 2020) and attention (e.g. Porges, 1993) are available for use in adults, and we are currently investigating their validity in a child and adolescent sample by assessing relationships between these interoception measures and individual difference measures known to be associated with them in adulthood (Barker, Brewer, Murphy, Viding, & Bird, 2019). It is also necessary to determine whether observers can reliably report on the interoceptive abilities of children. This will not only determine whether parents could report on child abilities where children are unable to unable to communicate or complete the questionnaires themselves, but also serve as an additional validation of the child self-report scales.

The aim of this research is to test the suitability of parent/guardian report questionnaires (referred to from now on as observer report) to assess the interoceptive accuracy and attention of typical, healthy children aged 6-18 years. By comparing the similarities between observer report and child self-report (CSR) on measures of interoceptive accuracy and attention, we hope to establish whether observer report alone is sufficient to obtain information about the child’s interoceptive abilities. If observer report can reliably predict CSR scores, this would support the use of observer report where necessary. Alternatively, if correlations between these measures are not strong, future work can determine which of these measures best predicts objective measures of interoceptive abilities, through association with objective measures. Furthermore, this research will measure the observer’s self-report of their own interoceptive accuracy and attention in order to examine whether this affects the correlations between observer report and CSR. If an observer reports personal difficulties with interoceptive accuracy and/or attention, this may limit the extent to which they can accurately perceive this ability in others (either due to observer’s own interoceptive difficulties making identification of others’ interoceptive states difficult, or observer’s low insight into interoceptive difficulties). The former may be analogous to difficulties recognising others’ emotions in those with alexithymia, who struggle to perceive and identify their own emotions (Grynberg et al., 2012). If the factors underlying atypical interoception also underlie the recognition of interoceptive states in others, it is essential to take the interoceptive abilities of an observer into account when considering the use of observer report in future research.

If observer reports can reliably predict CSR scores in healthy children, future use of these measures may provide additional information about the level of interoceptive insight present in those with mental health conditions associated with atypical interoception (e.g. large discrepancies between observer report and CSR for interoceptive accuracy may suggest the child has a low level of interoceptive insight for accuracy, especially if multiple observer measures correlate well). Since lack of insight may be an important factor in the development of some health conditions (rather than atypical accuracy or attention per se), this would be a valuable measure to develop and apply in future research. 

Observers should ideally be the child’s primary care-giver. However, if the primary care-giver is not available, any parent or guardian who knows the child well will be invited to complete the observer questionnaires. All observers will be asked to report their relationship to the child, in terms of biological relationship and caring role.

registration_responses.sample: Data will be collected until the sample reaches a minimum of 100 observer-child pairs (200 participants in total), or until the end of July 2020 if participant numbers exceed this. Based on a power calculation conducted in Gpower (Faul, Erdfelder, Buchner, & Lang, 2009), this will provide 80% power to detect an r value of .165 and above in a one-tailed test.
registration_responses.analyses:
Correlations will be used to determine the relationship between scores on the observer report and CSR, for the BPQ and IAS separately. Pearson and Spearman correlations will be used for data meeting and violating assumptions of parametric tests, respectively. 

Subsequent analyses will examine the extent to which the correlations between observer report and CSR change as a function of child age, sex, or observer interoceptive abilities. Firstly, whether child age, sex, or observer self-reported interoception interact with observer report in predicting child self-report will be investigated using enter method regression analyses. The following six regressions will be conducted:

Regression One: CSF IAS scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report IAS scores and child age as the predictor variable.

Regression Two: CSF IAS scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report IAS scores and child sex as the predictor variable.

Regression Three: CSF IAS scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report IAS score and observer’s self-reported IAS score as the predictor variable.

Regression Four: CSF BPQ scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report BPQ scores and child age as the predictor variable.

Regression Five: CSF BPQ scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report BPQ scores and child sex as the predictor variable.

Regression Six: CSF BPQ scores as the outcome variable. Interaction between observer report BPQ score and observer’s self-reported BPQ score as the predictor variable.

If assumptions for linear regressions are violated, entry method robust regressions using the default tuning function in MATLAB will be used. If serious issues with multicollinearity are encountered, ridge regressions will be used.

Secondly, the correlation coefficient for observer report and CSR for each observer and child pair will be calculated to compute a new variable, labelled “Observer-child consistency” (OCC). Two sets of OCC scores will be calculated for scores of accuracy (using IAS scores) and attention (using BPQ scores). All OCC scores will be standardised, and Z-scores will be used as a dependent variable for additional analyses. Correlations will be conducted to examine the relationship between OCC and age, as well as between OCC and observer’s self-report (for both accuracy and attention). T-tests will also be conducted to examine the differences between OCC accuracy and attention across male and female children.
registration_responses.outliers:
Participants whose first language is not English will be excluded from the analysis. For all measures, outliers greater than three standard deviations above or below the mean will be removed. If missing data for a given participant is greater than 75%, this participant’s data will be excluded. Otherwise, missing data will be imputed.

All children will be asked to report whether they feel like a boy or a girl to determine sex. A third option will also be presented (Other/Not Sure/I Don’t Know). Carers will also be asked the child’s biological sex at birth. Any child who chooses the third option, or any child whose gender identity differs from the sex at birth reported by their carer, will be excluded from the analyses, given that atypical gender identity could be a confounding factor for all analyses related to sex.
registration_responses.dependent:
The key variables of interest include:

Parent self-reported interoceptive accuracy: This will be measured using the Interoceptive Accuracy Scale (IAS; Appendix A), which is a recently developed measure of self-reported interoceptive accuracy (Murphy et al., 2020). The IAS requires participants to rate their accuracy in perceiving a range of body signals (e.g. “I can always accurately perceive when I need to urinate”).  The IAS contains 21 items rated on a scale from Strongly Agree (5) to Strongly Disagree (1). The range of scores is from 21-105, and higher scores indicate greater perceived interoceptive accuracy. Items in the scale are included based on either being related to typical sensations which have been described as interoceptive, or give rise to insula activation in the brain which is associated with interoceptive signal processing (Murphy et al., 2019).

Parent self-reported interoceptive attention: This will be measured using the awareness subscale of the Body Perception Questionnaire (BPQ; Porges, 1993; Appendix B). This scale has 45 items with answers on a five-point ordinal scale ranging from Never (1) to Always (5) and requires participants to rate their tendency to be aware of (notice) different body sensations (e.g. “Most of the time I am aware of my mouth being dry”).

CSR interoceptive attention: This will be measured using the simplified awareness subscale of the BPQ, adapted for children (Appendix C). This scale has 39 items with answers on a five-point ordinal scale ranging from Never (1) to Always (5). This scale was originally adapted for children by Palser, Fotopoulou, Pellicano and Kilner (2018). However, the present research will use more recent version which made minor edits to the adapted version for additional clarity (Barker et al., 2019).

CSR self-reported interoceptive accuracy: This will be measured using the child adaptation of the IAS (Barker et al., 2019; Appendix D). 

Observer report of child interoceptive attention: Observer report of interoceptive attention will be measured using a modified version of the awareness subscale of the BPQ (Appendix E). This version has been reworded so the questions are related to the perception of another person, rather than the individual completing the questionnaire (e.g. “Most of the time they are aware of their mouth being dry,” rather than “Most of the time I am aware of my mouth being dry.”). Additional instructions for the observer have been included to avoid potential ambiguity regarding how to answer the questions.  

Observer report of child interoceptive accuracy: Observer report of interoceptive attention will be measured using a modified version of the IAS (Appendix F). As above, this version has been reworded so the questions are related to the perception of another person, rather than the individual completing the questionnaire (e.g.  “They are always correct at feeling when they are hungry,” rather than “I am always correct at feeling when I am hungry.”) Additional instructions for the observer have been included to avoid potential ambiguity regarding how to answer the questions.  

Additional Demographic Information
A list of additional questions that participants will be asked can be found in Appendix G. These questions will be asked to obtain information relevant to our exclusion criteria (first language and atypical gender identity) as well as the primary and secondary analyses (sex, age and observer relationship to the child.
registration_responses.conditions: The study will have a correlational design, whereby child reports will be correlated with their respective parent reports. All participants will complete all measures designed for their age group.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Previous research has suggested that interoception, defined as the perception and awareness of one’s own internal state, may be implicated in the development of a range of psychiatric and neurodevelopmental disorders (e.g. Eggart, Lange, Binser, Queri, & Müller-Oerlinghausen, 2019; Khalsa et al., 2018; Murphy, Brewer, Catmur, & Bird, 2017; Pang et al., 2019). Because of this, it is crucial to form an in-depth understanding of how, when and why atypical interoception occurs. Since this understanding relies on the accurate and reliable measurement of interoceptive abilities, it is important that measures are validated for use across a range of ages and cognitive abilities. While valid objective measures of interoceptive accuracy and attention should be the gold standard, existing objective measures have a number of limitations (Murphy, Brewer, Coll et al., 2019; Murphy, Brewer, Hobson, Catmur, & Bird, 2018; Ring, Brener, Knapp, & Mailloux, 2015) and are often too time-consuming for developmental studies. Self-report measures assessing both accuracy (Murphy et al., 2020) and attention (e.g. Porges, 1993) are available for use in adults, and we are currently investigating their validity in a child and adolescent sample by assessing relationships between these interoception measures and individual difference measures known to be associated with them in adulthood (Barker, Brewer, Murphy, Viding, & Bird, 2019). It is also necessary to determine whether observers can reliably report on the interoceptive abilities of children. This will not only determine whether parents could report on child abilities where children are unable to unable to communicate or complete the questionnaires themselves, but also serve as an additional validation of the child self-report scales.

The aim of this research is to test the suitability of parent/guardian report questionnaires (referred to from now on as observer report) to assess the interoceptive accuracy and attention of typical, healthy children aged 6-18 years. By comparing the similarities between observer report and child self-report (CSR) on measures of interoceptive accuracy and attention, we hope to establish whether observer report alone is sufficient to obtain information about the child’s interoceptive abilities. If observer report can reliably predict CSR scores, this would support the use of observer report where necessary. Alternatively, if correlations between these measures are not strong, future work can determine which of these measures best predicts objective measures of interoceptive abilities, through association with objective measures. Furthermore, this research will measure the observer’s self-report of their own interoceptive accuracy and attention in order to examine whether this affects the correlations between observer report and CSR. If an observer reports personal difficulties with interoceptive accuracy and/or attention, this may limit the extent to which they can accurately perceive this ability in others (either due to observer’s own interoceptive difficulties making identification of others’ interoceptive states difficult, or observer’s low insight into interoceptive difficulties). The former may be analogous to difficulties recognising others’ emotions in those with alexithymia, who struggle to perceive and identify their own emotions (Grynberg et al., 2012). If the factors underlying atypical interoception also underlie the recognition of interoceptive states in others, it is essential to take the interoceptive abilities of an observer into account when considering the use of observer report in future research.

If observer reports can reliably predict CSR scores in healthy children, future use of these measures may provide additional information about the level of interoceptive insight present in those with mental health conditions associated with atypical interoception (e.g. large discrepancies between observer report and CSR for interoceptive accuracy may suggest the child has a low level of interoceptive insight for accuracy, especially if multiple observer measures correlate well). Since lack of insight may be an important factor in the development of some health conditions (rather than atypical accuracy or attention per se), this would be a valuable measure to develop and apply in future research. 

Observers should ideally be the child’s primary care-giver. However, if the primary care-giver is not available, any parent or guardian who knows the child well will be invited to complete the observer questionnaires. All observers will be asked to report their relationship to the child, in terms of biological relationship and caring role.

attributes.title: Inter-species action copying between humans and chimpanzees
attributes.description: This study has two main aims. First, we will assess the rates of inter-species spontaneous imitation between captive chimpanzees and human visitors replicating and building upon previous studies. Second, this study will experimentally evaluate the influence that several factors (both subject- and action-specific) have on the probability of an action to be imitated by chimpanzees.

attributes.title: Individual variability in touch attitudes and experience
attributes.description: Prior evidence has shown that attitudes to and experiences of touch vary according to a number of individual difference factors, such as age (Sehlstedt et al., 2016), gender (Trotter, McGlone, Reniers & Deakin, 2018), cultural background (Dibiase & Gunnoe, 2004) personality (Dorros, Hanzal & Segrin, 2008), attachment style (Krahé et al., 2018), body image (Scheffer et al., 2017) and autistic traits (Voos, Pelphrey & Kaiser, 2013). The current study, a collaboration with the BBC and the Wellcome Collection examines interindividual differences associated with touch attitudes in a large and diverse sample. In addition, we will examine variables that have not to our knowledge been investigated previously in relation to touch attitudes. These will include interoceptive awareness, and the occurrence of visual impairment. We will also carry out analyses of the reliability, validity, and factor structure of two dominant measures of touch attitudes within our sample.

q2.value:
The following predictions relating to individual variability in attitudes towards touch are made for a UK adult sample, who do not report experience of long-term health conditions or impairments:

1)	Based on prior research identifying a correlation between age and attitudes to social touch, we predict that older adults will express more positive attitudes towards touch than younger adults, as measured on the Social Touch Questionnaire (STQ; Wilhem et al) and the Touch Experiences and Attitudes Questionnaire (TEAQ; Trotter et al., 2018). Note, prior work did not find associations between scores on the TEAQ and age, but the broader literature would suggest a relationship will be likely, and therefore we predict this effect. 

2)	Following prior research identifying gender differences in attitudes to/experiences of touch (Trotter et al., 2018), we predict that females will report more positive attitudes towards touch than males, as measured on the STQ and the TEAQ, with the exception of items relating to intimate forms of touch, where gender differences have not been reported previously.

3)	Previous research has demonstrated that trait agreeableness and openness to experience are associated with differences in touch attitudes/experiences (e.g. Dorros et al. 2008). We predict that higher trait agreeableness, and higher openness to experience will both be associated with more positive attitudes towards touch on the STQ and the TEAQ. Based on previous work, we predict to see associations between agreeableness and all touch attitude items, but for openness to experience this relationship is predicted only for items relating to non-intimate forms of touch. Trait extraversion has also been linked to increased somatosensory cortical activity in response to touch. We therefore predict to see differences in attitudes to touch in relation to trait extraversion. Given that extraverted individuals are more motivated to engage in social contact (Wilt & Revelle, 2009), we predict that high extraversion will be associated with more positive attitudes to touch on the STQ and the TEAQ. Specifically, we predict to see associations for items pertaining to social forms of touch.

4)	Anxious attachment in relationships has previously been linked to increased effectiveness of pleasant (C-tactile afferent) touch in reducing pain; while avoidant attachment is associated with reduced effectiveness of pleasant touch in pain reduction (Krahé et al., 2018). Avoidant attachment has also been linked to reduced enjoyment of social interaction with a romantic partner. We predict that a more avoidant attachment style will be associated with less positive attitudes towards touch on the STQ and TEAQ. We predict that a more anxious attachment style will be associated with more positive attitudes towards touch, and specifically that the largest effect sizes will be observed for subscales related to intimate touch, which refer to stroking or caressing (i.e. C-T optimal touch).

5)	Prior work has shown that interoceptive awareness is associated with differences in the perceived pleasantness of touch (Crucianelli et al., 2018). Additionally, it has been argued that pleasant (C-tactile afferent) touch should be considered a form of interoception, due to shared anatomical pathways with other aspects of interoceptive processing (Björnsdotter, Morrison & Olausson, 2010; Craig, 2003). Disorders of body image have also been linked to poor interoceptive accuracy (Pollatos et al., 2008). We therefore predict to see more positive touch attitudes on the STQ and the TEAQ for individuals with greater interoceptive accuracy. Specifically, we predict an association with items relating to intimate touch, which refer to stroking or caressing.

6)	Based on previous work identifying an association between body image and comfort with physical touch (Orbach & Mikulincer, 1998), greater body acceptance is predicted to be associated with more positive attitudes towards touch on the STQ and the TEAQ, across all items.

The hypotheses above relating to age, gender, personality, attachment style, interoceptive awareness and body acceptance are made for a UK adult sample. However, prior research has identified geographical differences in social touch behaviour. We predict that individual differences in touch attitudes will also differ between groups of participants based in different countries. Our survey is available worldwide, and based on prior surveys of this type that have been conducted by the BBC and Wellcome Collection, we envisage suitable sample sizes are likely in additional European and North American countries. However, as an opportunity sampling method is being used, we will not know the location of all participants until the study closes. As such, while we expect to see variation in the factors predicting touch attitudes across different countries, we refrain from making specific directional hypotheses at this time.

Additional groups of interest in relation to individual differences in touch attitudes include participants with autism spectrum conditions, and visual or mobility impairments. These analyses will likely form a separate paper, depending upon the sample of size of participants recruited who report these conditions. Further details on this analysis will be registered as an additional subproject once sample sizes have been ascertained after the data collection is completed and accessed (this is because we will not know participant numbers in each group until the survey is finished).

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales. For a full list of survey contents, see the attached document. See Variables section for further detail on the scales relevant to the current project. We will extract the relevant scales outlined in the Variables section from this dataset to exploring specific questions linked to this project.

q7.value: All participants were asked to complete all of the measures described in the Variables section. The order of these variables was partly randomised between participants using Qualtrics survey software. The order of randomised blocks is provided in the attachment to Study Design. Within particular scales, items were presented in a standard order to maintain consistency with prior work.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q9.value: Data collection for this project has already begun but is not yet completed. It is currently held online on the Qualtrics survey platform. The data will be accessed and analysed after data collection is completed on 30/03/2020.

question.value: Participants have been recruited through broadcasts on the BBC and other media. There is no monetary incentive to take part. Participants must be aged over 18 years old and have internet access on a computer, smart phone or tablet to participate.

q11.value: Our target sample size is a minimum of 240 for each sample that we plan to analyse (based on G-Power calculations). We will collect a large opportunity sample with the aim of recruiting at least this number of participants for each sample of interest (for example, participants based in countries outside of the UK). Note that our stopping criteria are restricted by date (30/03/2020) as the project is a collaboration with the BBC/Wellcome Collection and the stopping date is set by these partners. Based on similar prior projects run by BBC/Wellcome Collection we envisage a minimum sample of ~20,000 participants from the UK.

Since we anticipate being able to recruit a large participant sample for the project, a more stringent alpha level of .01 was selected for the regression analysis.

question.value:
The study is an online self-report survey comprising several independent scales. Variables of interest for the current project are described below, in the order administered. For a full list of survey contents, see attached document in Study Design.

The 20-item Social Touch Questionnaire (STQ; Wilhelm, Kochar, Ross & Gross, 2001) measuring attitudes towards social touch. Responses from a Portuguese sample have previously identified three underlying subscales, representing Dislike of Physical Touch, Liking of Familiar Physical Touch, and Liking of Public Physical Touch (Vieira et al, 2016).

The 15-item GSEOP Big Five Inventory (BFI-S; Hahn, Gottschling & Spinath, 2012), comprising five subscales identifying trait Neuroticism, Extraversion, Openness to Experience, Agreeableness and Conscientiousness.

Demographic questions:
Age 
Employment status
Main field of work
Do you think that touch plays an important role in your work? (Five-point Likert scale from Strongly Disagree to Strongly Agree)
Gender
Sexual orientation 
Country of residence
(If UK) Region of the UK
(If UK) Ethnicity
Religion
Disability, long-term condition or impairment

12 items selected from the Touch Attitudes and Experiences Questionnaire (TEAQ; Trotter et al., 2018), examining touch attitudes and experiences. These items represent six subscales relating to: Childhood Touch, Friends and Family Touch, Current Intimate Touch, Attitude to Intimate Touch, Attitude to Self-Care, and Attitude to Unfamiliar Touch.

A 12-item version of the Experiences in Close Relationships Questionnaire (ECR-12; Lafontaine et al., 2015) measuring Anxiety and Avoidance in adult attachment.

The 20-item Interoceptive Accuracy Scale (IAS; Murphy et al., 2020) measuring self-reported interoceptive accuracy (i.e. the ability to accurately detect internal bodily sensations).

Five items comprising the Body Acceptance subscale of the Dresden Body Image Questionnaire (Scheffers et al., 2017), identifying the level of acceptance of one’s own body.

Items from standardised scales (described above) will be combined to create scale and subscale scores according to published scoring instructions.

An exploratory factor analysis will be carried out on items from the STQ and the TEAQ combined (see Analysis Plan). If common underlying factors are identified in this analysis, subscale scores may be generated based on these results.

The following analyses are planned:

N.B. Analyses 1-5 will be carried out on a typical adult sample who currently reside in the UK, and indicate on the survey that “I do not have any disability, long-term condition or impairment”.

1)	 Analysis of the factor structure underlying the STQ and the TEAQ in our sample, using factor analysis. This will likely form a stand-alone paper.

Confirmatory factor analysis will be used to examine the STQ, to confirm a previously reported three-factor structure in our sample.

Exploratory factor analysis will be used to examine the TEAQ, given that this is a relatively new measure, and that the current survey used only 12 items (the two highest loading items on each of six subscales) from the full 57-item scale.

In addition, we will run an exploratory factor analysis on the 39 items from the STQ and TEAQ combined, to identify common latent variables underlying the two measures of touch attitudes.

2)	Analysis of the reliability of responses on the STQ and the TEAQ. The Cronbach’s alpha statistic will be calculated as a measure of internal consistency on these scales.

3)	Analysis of the convergent validity of touch attitude scales. To examine this we will run Pearson’s correlation analyses to identify the relation between the STQ and the TEAQ. Since both scales are intended to measure similar constructs, scores are expected to correlate with one another.

4)	Analysis of individual differences associated with attitudes towards touch. This will likely form another stand-alone paper.

The following continuous variables will be correlated with STQ and TEAQ scores:

Age
Gender
Personality traits (Agreeableness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Openness to Experience, Neuroticism)
Attachment (Anxious, Avoidant)
Interoceptive Awareness
Body Acceptance
Day of completion or week of completion depending on number of survey respondents (to be defined after data is accessed). 
Do you think that touch plays an important role in your work?

For significant correlations (defined as p <.005), data will be entered into regression analyses to test the relative contribution of a given predictor variable, while controlling for: age, gender, study completion date, and other significant correlates.

5)	Analysis of the impact of Covid-19 on touch attitudes. This will likely form another stand-alone paper.

The data for this project have been collected during a period of escalating concern over Covid-19, which is likely to have changed participants attitudes towards social touch. We address this above by including the day/week of survey completion as a predictor variable in our regression analyses above, to examine how touch attitudes might have changed as the risk associated with social touch increased. 

In addition, we also propose to examine how attitudes towards vary as a function of time points in geographical regions by comparing attitudes towards touch responses before ten cases of Covid-19 and after ten cases of Covid-19 in a given region of interest (e.g. in England – before 24/02/20 versus after 24/02/20 based on cases reported by Public Health England). Comparisons will be made with ANOVA or non-parametric alternative (e.g. permutation tests). For these between-group comparisons linked to Covid-19, groups will be compared to check for any differences in control variables of interest (based on existing prior literature), including age, gender, openness to experience, agreeableness, and attachment style. If groupings differ in these variables (e.g. age, gender), these factors will be controlled for by conducting ANCOVA or by adding relevant factors as main effects in ANOVA analyses. Any main effects in the ANOVA will be followed up with Bonferroni corrected pair-wise comparisons. The grouping analysis linked to Covid-19 will likely form a separate paper with potential to additionally focus on geographical differences depending upon the sample of size of participants recruited from a specific country or sub-region (e.g. regional differences within the UK). Further details on any country specific analysis outside of the UK will be registered as an additional subproject once sample sizes have been ascertained after the data collection is completed and accessed (this is because we will not know the proportion of people from different geographical regions who have completed the survey at different time points until the survey is finished).

6)	Analysis of individual differences in touch attitudes worldwide.

At a minimum we will conduct our analyses above on participants from the UK. Where possible we will also explore additional European and North American countries, where suitable sample sizes (minimum 240 participants) can be collected. In this case, Analysis 4 will be repeated for these countries. Following these analyses, Fisher’s R to Z transformations will be carried out to examine whether relationships between individual difference factors and touch attitudes differ between these groups and the UK sample. These may form separate papers or be combined with our approaches outlined above.

q18.value:
Gender will be included as a control variable in regression analyses described in the Analysis Plan. To achieve this, gender categories (recorded as Man, Non-Binary, Woman) will be dummy coded.
Assumptions of normality will be checked using gg-plots, histograms, and tests of normality (e.g., Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests). For moderate skew or kurtosis, log-transformations or similar will be applied. For extreme deviations from normality, we will use equivalent non-parametric tests. Any deviations or alterations to these plans will be reported. 
For group comparisons we will remove any outliers that are three standard deviations away from the group average. We will also compare data with and without group outliers as a sensitivity analysis.

To deal with outliers in our regression analyses we will use robust regressions where relevant.

q19.value: We will use the following alpha levels: <.005 for all correlations, <.01 given sample size for all regressions, <.05 for group level comparisons. Bonferroni correction will be applied to follow up on any group level comparisons where relevant (e.g. following ANOVAs).

Subscales will be treated individually, where a participant may be excluded from analysis for one subscale, but can still be included in analyses for other subscales on that scale, where data is sufficient.

q22.value:
We think it is likely that differences in touch attitudes will differ between participants based in different regions of the UK. We will therefore compare the attitudes of groups of participants from different regions in an exploratory analysis. This analysis will be registered as a further subproject once sample sizes have been ascertained. 

We may also conduct additional exploratory analyses following our assessment of the factor structure of the STQ and TEAQ using cluster analysis approaches (e.g. k-means, finite mixture models, finite mixture models of regression models) to identify sub-groups of participants based on their attitudes towards touch. We will then seek to compare any sub-groups on variables of interest outlined above using alpha criteria outlined above. The purpose of this will be to take advantage of what we anticipate to be one of the largest and most up-to-date datasets on attitudes and experiences of touch with a view to providing a detailed taxonomy of individual differences in the touch attitudes/experiences in order promote future research. Note, that in this context we may in future work also seek to explore additional items from the full Touch Test survey (attached) that are not mentioned as part of our planned analyses above.

In the context of Covid-19 we may also adopt a generalised linear mixed model (GLMM) approach in order to quantify how Covid-19 is linked to changes in attitudes towards touch. Further, given the unprecedented nature of Covid-19 there is also a high likelihood that additional analyses of interest will arise within our research team or the wider community. 

In all scientific communications, any exploratory or additional analyses will be clearly labelled as such. Further, any deviations from these analyses will be noted. Where possible, we will pre-register future re-analyses of these data, for example as part of student projects or similar.

registration_responses.q2:
The following predictions relating to individual variability in attitudes towards touch are made for a UK adult sample, who do not report experience of long-term health conditions or impairments:

1)	Based on prior research identifying a correlation between age and attitudes to social touch, we predict that older adults will express more positive attitudes towards touch than younger adults, as measured on the Social Touch Questionnaire (STQ; Wilhem et al) and the Touch Experiences and Attitudes Questionnaire (TEAQ; Trotter et al., 2018). Note, prior work did not find associations between scores on the TEAQ and age, but the broader literature would suggest a relationship will be likely, and therefore we predict this effect. 

2)	Following prior research identifying gender differences in attitudes to/experiences of touch (Trotter et al., 2018), we predict that females will report more positive attitudes towards touch than males, as measured on the STQ and the TEAQ, with the exception of items relating to intimate forms of touch, where gender differences have not been reported previously.

3)	Previous research has demonstrated that trait agreeableness and openness to experience are associated with differences in touch attitudes/experiences (e.g. Dorros et al. 2008). We predict that higher trait agreeableness, and higher openness to experience will both be associated with more positive attitudes towards touch on the STQ and the TEAQ. Based on previous work, we predict to see associations between agreeableness and all touch attitude items, but for openness to experience this relationship is predicted only for items relating to non-intimate forms of touch. Trait extraversion has also been linked to increased somatosensory cortical activity in response to touch. We therefore predict to see differences in attitudes to touch in relation to trait extraversion. Given that extraverted individuals are more motivated to engage in social contact (Wilt & Revelle, 2009), we predict that high extraversion will be associated with more positive attitudes to touch on the STQ and the TEAQ. Specifically, we predict to see associations for items pertaining to social forms of touch.

4)	Anxious attachment in relationships has previously been linked to increased effectiveness of pleasant (C-tactile afferent) touch in reducing pain; while avoidant attachment is associated with reduced effectiveness of pleasant touch in pain reduction (Krahé et al., 2018). Avoidant attachment has also been linked to reduced enjoyment of social interaction with a romantic partner. We predict that a more avoidant attachment style will be associated with less positive attitudes towards touch on the STQ and TEAQ. We predict that a more anxious attachment style will be associated with more positive attitudes towards touch, and specifically that the largest effect sizes will be observed for subscales related to intimate touch, which refer to stroking or caressing (i.e. C-T optimal touch).

5)	Prior work has shown that interoceptive awareness is associated with differences in the perceived pleasantness of touch (Crucianelli et al., 2018). Additionally, it has been argued that pleasant (C-tactile afferent) touch should be considered a form of interoception, due to shared anatomical pathways with other aspects of interoceptive processing (Björnsdotter, Morrison & Olausson, 2010; Craig, 2003). Disorders of body image have also been linked to poor interoceptive accuracy (Pollatos et al., 2008). We therefore predict to see more positive touch attitudes on the STQ and the TEAQ for individuals with greater interoceptive accuracy. Specifically, we predict an association with items relating to intimate touch, which refer to stroking or caressing.

6)	Based on previous work identifying an association between body image and comfort with physical touch (Orbach & Mikulincer, 1998), greater body acceptance is predicted to be associated with more positive attitudes towards touch on the STQ and the TEAQ, across all items.

The hypotheses above relating to age, gender, personality, attachment style, interoceptive awareness and body acceptance are made for a UK adult sample. However, prior research has identified geographical differences in social touch behaviour. We predict that individual differences in touch attitudes will also differ between groups of participants based in different countries. Our survey is available worldwide, and based on prior surveys of this type that have been conducted by the BBC and Wellcome Collection, we envisage suitable sample sizes are likely in additional European and North American countries. However, as an opportunity sampling method is being used, we will not know the location of all participants until the study closes. As such, while we expect to see variation in the factors predicting touch attitudes across different countries, we refrain from making specific directional hypotheses at this time.

Additional groups of interest in relation to individual differences in touch attitudes include participants with autism spectrum conditions, and visual or mobility impairments. These analyses will likely form a separate paper, depending upon the sample of size of participants recruited who report these conditions. Further details on this analysis will be registered as an additional subproject once sample sizes have been ascertained after the data collection is completed and accessed (this is because we will not know participant numbers in each group until the survey is finished).

attributes.title: The status of semantic memory in MTL amnesia varies with demands on scene construction
attributes.description: To investigate whether semantic memory impairments in MTL amnesia can be understood with reference to a deficit in scene construction, the current study examined knowledge of scripts that vary in the extent to which they play out in a scene context in nine patients with MTL amnesia and eighteen healthy control subjects.  Scripts are routine activities characterized by an ordered set of actions, including some that are essential for completing the activity. Comparing performance on scene-based scripts (e.g., buying groceries at the grocery store) and object-based scripts (e.g., addressing a letter), we found that patients generated the same number of total action steps as controls for both types of script, but patients were selectively impaired at generating essential actions steps for scene-based scripts.  Furthermore, patients made more sequencing and idiosyncratic errors than controls in the scene-based, but not in the object-based, scripts.  These findings demonstrate that the hippocampus plays a critical role in the retrieval of semantic knowledge about everyday activities when such retrieval entails scene construction.

attributes.title: The influence of explicit probability information on preparation and performance
attributes.description: The present online experiment is part of a study examining how participants prepare and execute novel instructions when explicit probability information regarding the task occurrence is provided.

q1.value: Christina Reimer, Zhang Chen, Frederick Verbruggen

q2.value:
With regards to self-paced duration of the preparation phase (prepRT), we predict that it will be shorter in the 25%-image-alone-condition than in the 75%-image-alone condition. After all, in the 25%-image-alone condition, the correct response is provided on most of the trials; whereas in the 75%-image-alone condition, participants have to rely mostly on the instructed S-R mappings to give the correct response. Even though participants do not know in advance which trials will be image-alone or image-and-letter trials, we do predict that participants will prepare less in the 25%-image-alone condition, resulting in (on average) shorter prepRT.
With regards to performance in the execution phase, we can contrast two accounts: the ’preparation’ account and the ’attentional orienting’ account. The ’preparation’ account predicts poorer task performance (on average lower ACC and longer exeRT) on image-alone trials in the 25%- compared with the 75%- image-alone condition (as participants are less likely to prepare/implement the instructions in the former condition). According to this account, performance should be similar on image-and-letter trials in both conditions (as no preparation of S-R mappings is required on these trials). The ’attentional orienting’ account predicts longer exeRT (and possibly lower ACC) for the infrequent event. Thus, for image-alone trials, it makes similar predictions as the ’preparation’ account; i.e. longer exeRT (and possibly lower ACC) in the 25%-image-alone condition compared with the 75%-image-alone condition. However, it predicts the reversed pattern for image-and-letter trials; i.e. longer exeRT (and possible lower ACC) in the 75% image-alone condition compared with the 25% image-alone condition.

registration_responses.q1: Christina Reimer, Zhang Chen, Frederick Verbruggen
registration_responses.q2:
With regards to self-paced duration of the preparation phase (prepRT), we predict that it will be shorter in the 25%-image-alone-condition than in the 75%-image-alone condition. After all, in the 25%-image-alone condition, the correct response is provided on most of the trials; whereas in the 75%-image-alone condition, participants have to rely mostly on the instructed S-R mappings to give the correct response. Even though participants do not know in advance which trials will be image-alone or image-and-letter trials, we do predict that participants will prepare less in the 25%-image-alone condition, resulting in (on average) shorter prepRT.
With regards to performance in the execution phase, we can contrast two accounts: the ’preparation’ account and the ’attentional orienting’ account. The ’preparation’ account predicts poorer task performance (on average lower ACC and longer exeRT) on image-alone trials in the 25%- compared with the 75%- image-alone condition (as participants are less likely to prepare/implement the instructions in the former condition). According to this account, performance should be similar on image-and-letter trials in both conditions (as no preparation of S-R mappings is required on these trials). The ’attentional orienting’ account predicts longer exeRT (and possibly lower ACC) for the infrequent event. Thus, for image-alone trials, it makes similar predictions as the ’preparation’ account; i.e. longer exeRT (and possibly lower ACC) in the 25%-image-alone condition compared with the 75%-image-alone condition. However, it predicts the reversed pattern for image-and-letter trials; i.e. longer exeRT (and possible lower ACC) in the 75% image-alone condition compared with the 25% image-alone condition.

attributes.title: Vaccination
attributes.description: This study tests the effect of an intervention on seasonal flu vaccination behaviour among Healthcare Workers (HCW).

data.value: Yes, we already collected the data.

name.value: Planning to not Regret! A Randomised Controlled Trial on Increasing the Seasonal Flu Vaccination Rate

other.value: We expected that HCW involved in the intervention group have significantly higher scores at time 2 (T2) on variables of the HAPA (Schwarzer, 2001), such as self-efficacy, risk perception and outcome expectancies (Hypothesis 5) compared to Time 1 (T1) and the HCW in others groups at T2. Finally, this study investigated the predictors of vaccination behaviour (Hypothesis 6) and vaccination intention (Hypothesis 7).

sample.value: We wanted to recruit a minimum of 33 participants per group at T2, 132 HCW in total, to complete this study (power =.80, alpha =.05, d =.59; Gollwitzer & Sheeran, 2006; R-Studio version 3.4.4.)

analyses.value: Analyses were only performed on unvaccinated participants at T1 to verify the effectiveness of the intervention. A binomial logistic regression was performed to test the effect of the group type on the vaccination behaviour at T2 (Hypothesis 1). Two contrasts were executed. Then the effect of the group type on vaccination intention of HCW at T2 (Hypothesis 2) was tested. A correction was applied because of a non-normal distribution, but the distributions remained non-normal. A Kruskal-Wallis test was used with vaccination intention at T2 as a dependent variable and group type as an independent variable. Then a Wilcoxon test was executed to test the differences between the three groups. The same analyses are performed for hypotheses 3 and 4.

outliers.value: The HCW who were not able to speak or read French were excluded.

dependent.value:
At Time 2, the HCW were asked to enter their vaccination status and their vaccination intention for the following year. 

-vaccination intention (3 items; Armitage & Conner, 2001): e.g. "I intend to get vaccinated against seasonal flu soon."

conditions.value: The first group watched a two-minute video. The second group completed first the anticipated regret then planning technique (i.e. action planning and coping planning). The third group received the entire intervention (first video, then anticipated regret and planning technique). The fourth group was control group

hypothesis.value: We predicted a significantly higher vaccination rate (Hypothesis 1) and vaccination intention (Hypothesis 2) at T2 among HCW in the intervention group (video consisting of targeted information, planning technique and anticipated regret) compared to the three other groups: control group, video group and planning technique and anticipated regret group. We hypothesised that HCW with at least a low vaccination intention who correctly completed the planning technique would have a significantly higher vaccination rate (Hypothesis 3) and vaccination intention (Hypothesis 4) than the other groups.

attributes.title: Long Term vs. Immediate Benefits of Healthiness
attributes.description: This study seeks to examine whether people are less willing to make a donation when a wealthy person asks them to do so vs. when an average person asks them to do so.

q2.value: H1: Participants will be significantly less likely to donate when the request comes from a wealthy person than when the request comes from a less wealthy person.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: Participants will be told about an individual named Rob who is making a donation to an organization and  requesting others to do the same. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions: wealthy person donation request vs. control donation request. Those in the wealthy person condition will be told that Rob is a billionaire and those in the control will be told that he is a local man in the community. They read that he has made a $75 donation to a hospital that he grew up near, and is asking others to make a donation as well. Participants will be asked whether they are willing to donate a $0.10 bonus to a hospital in New Jersey. Afterwards, they will be asked question about their perception of Rob's wealth to verify that the manipulation worked as intended.

q7.value: The study will be administered through Qualtrics, in which case the system will automatically randomize whether participants are put into the control or wealthy Rob condition.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: This study is being run after another study, and the other study needs to recruit participants between the ages of 18 and 40. Therefore, only participants between these ages will participate in the study.

q11.value: 150 participants will be recruited to this study so that there are at least 75 participants per condition.

q12.value: This study has money constraints, and therefore we are recruiting 150 participants.

q13.value: This study is being posted on TurkPrime, and therefore we will stop collection when TurkPrime says that 150 participants have been collected. Please note that sometimes TurkPrime includes a few extra participants in the data, and therefore there may be more than 150. Thus, the stopping rule will be when TurkPrime states that the study has been completed.

question.value: We will manipulate whether participants are told that Rob is a billionaire or that he is a local man in New Jersey.

We will measure whether participants agree to donate their $0.10 bonus, as well as demographic characteristics (age, income, gender, location, education). We will also measure whether they think rob is extremely wealthy and rich (manipulation check).
We will use a logistic regression to analyze whether the condition predicts willingness to donate.

q20.value: Participants must complete the DV, the choice of whether or not to donate, to be included in the final analyses. No other participants data will be excluded.

q21.value: All missing data will be left missing.

q22.value: We will ask exploratory questions about whether Rob could give more than he has, whether it is appropriate for Rob to ask people to pay for his causes, whether he is making a sacrifice, whether he is moral, generous, good, or kind. We will use these as exploratory to help guide future studies as to the meditational process.
